Award.AwardTitle: Validating a Rapid Measure of Student Motivation: Using the Expectancy-Value Theory of Motivation to Understand Student Achievement and Interest in STEM Classrooms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This full scale project focuses on the development of a rapid, validated scale. The scale will be used by teachers, administrators, and evaluators to measure student motivation in accordance with a theoretical view grounded in Expectancy-Value Theory (EVT). The project features a mixed methods approach to establishing the valid and reliable measure along with an established validity framework seeking six types of validity and reliability.

By developing and validating the measure, the project team members will add to education and evaluation theory in terms of informing understanding of the cost factor in the Expectancy-Value-Cost model of motivation. In terms of practical applicability, the resulting scale will be available for widespread use to predict important learning indicators and inform potential further interventions with students to improve motivation and other learning outcomes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Motivation plays an essential role in students’ academic performance and engagement. Thus, knowledge of students’ motivation is critical in understanding and designing educational environments that will promote optimal student outcomes, especially in contexts when students tend to have low expectancies for success or low value for engaging in classroom activities (e.g., Cohen et al., 2009; Hulleman & Harackiewicz, 2009). A variety of motivation instruments have been developed and used in different settings for this purpose (e.g., Eccles & Wigfield, 1995; Duncan & McKeachie, 2005), but many possess key limitations for routine, widespread use in education, particularly in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics classrooms (i.e., STEM). The purpose of this project was to develop, test, and recommend a theoretically-grounded, practical measure of student motivation that can be readily used in STEM educational contexts. The analytic sample for piloting and field-testing versions of the instrument consisted of over 15 study sites and over 19,000 students in a variety of science and math courses.

The new motivation instrument is rapid and practical (low response burden), intuitive, and grounded in social cognitive theories of achievement motivation. In particular, the motivation instrument is based on the Expectancy-Value Theory (EVT) of motivation, a framework that has provided a rigorous model of factors that contribute to motivation and achievement for several decades (e.g., Eccles et al, 1983; Wigfield & Eccles, 2000; Pintrich, Conley, & Kempler, 2003). This framework compares the relationship between students’ Expectancy for success at a task, in parallel with their perceived Value for engaging in the task. The current instrument extends prior work by incorporating Cost as a factor that may mitigate or interact with expectancy and value, thus serving to decrease motivation. We used a combination of validity evidence to evaluate individual items and the overall instrument, including content (e.g., review by experts in psychology and measurement, interviews with teachers and students), internal (e.g., confirmatory factor analysis, factor correlations, reliability), known-groups (e.g., invariance testing), predictive (e.g., scale correlations with student achievement and future interest in STEM), and practical (e.g., could the items be completed in five minutes or less, do participants experience response fatigue) validity.

The resulting expectancy-value-cost instrument is 8-10 items and can be administered from middle school through early college in a variety of STEM educational settings (see also Expectancy-Value-Cost Survey of Student Motivation User’s Guide; Barron, Hulleman, Getty, & Taylor, 2017). Development work and piloting of items show that the instrument is reliable across different student demographics (i.e., invariance testing), and that it can be used to identify and understand motivation “gaps,” as well as the effectiveness of targeted interventions. The instrument also displays strong predictive validity in showing how expectancy, value, and cost factors relate to important outcomes such as achievement and future interest in STEM. As such, the instrument will be particularly beneficial to evaluators, researchers, and practitioners in STEM classrooms for measuring the degree to which targeted motivation interventions or teaching innovations or technologies may increase student motivation in STEM.

Our initial data show that expectancies can have strong correlations with achievement, and that cost can have a pronounced negative relationship. Yet importantly, science and math practitioners strive to support not only achievement but also future interest in science, math, or technology disciplines. Thus, in many cases it is beneficial for practitioners, researchers, or evaluators to couple with achievement measures an additional outcome measure for future interest in science or math. A key implication for practitioners is that this future interest indicator correlated most highly with students having a high value for their class. Thus, teachers or even curriculum developers wishing to promote future interest in STEM would likely benefit highly from strategies or approaches that promote value for their students.

Through the project, we also found benefit to gathering site-specific, qualitative data to complement the main goal of collecting quantitative data with our rapid, practical measure. Specifically, we added two open-ended, qualitative questions to allow participants an opportunity to list reasons why they were motivated, or not motivated, in a particular course. We discovered that the addition of qualitative questions provided a rich list of site-specific, contextual formative data on how to promote and increase expectancy, values, and costs in particular classes. This may not have been as apparent with just the quantitative likert items. Findings from these optional, qualitative items have also informed professional development with practitioners at middle and high school and college level at a number of our study sites, and are suggested as an extremely useful element to add to the rapid, quantitative expectancy-value-cost mostivation scale.
